direction.raw_text: A trio of TEENAGE GIRLS (one white, one Asian, one black) come running out from the wings and start dancing and rapping. The audience loves them.

dialogue.raw_text: High school is like the training wheels for the bicycle of real life. It is a time for young people to explore different fields of interest and to hopefully grow from their experiences.  After all, that which we learn from our mistakes can be as valuable as what we learn from our textbooks, and often we can turn the negative experiences that are common to all high-schoolers into positive steps toward personal growth and achievement. In coming to terms with my own personal setback, which I'm sure you've all heard about, I've been able to learn a lot about myself. I've learned for one thing that I don't need to rely on drugs and alcohol (APPLAUSE) and that I'm very lucky-that more people besides Carrie and myself weren't hurt in the accident; I've learned that I'm blessed with wonderful parents, teachers and above all the best classmates in the world -- I love each and every one of you guys!! (APPLAUSE) and I've learned that to get through life's obstacles you need faith, hope and, most of all, a sense of humor. (BIG APPLAUSE)

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA reaches the top of the stairs, we see a door that slowly CREAKS open. We move into the room beyond, it's decorated with stuff from the 50's and a giant crucifix. We HEAR a televangelist's sermon. We MOVE CLOSE on a little girl's doll. Very slowly a MAN'S HAND reaches for the doll and drags it into the shadows. The hand throws the now mutilated doll into a toilet; water and blood swirl around. We see grainy footage (shot off of TV) of Christians angrily picketing an abortion clinic. CREDITS come up: THE END.  A FILM BY ROBERTA ALLSWORTH.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lights go on, the VIDEO ends and the monitor is shut off. There are about a dozen students, mostly pimply 14-year-old boys, a few 14-ish girls, and Enid, dressed in schoolgirl outfit. The teacher, ROBERTA ALLSWORTH, addresses the class.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That piece is entitled "Mirror/Father/Mirror." I like to show it to people I'm meeting for the first time because it says so much about who I am and what it feels like to inhabit my specific skin. And this is exactly what I'm hoping to get from each of you over the course of this Summer: a picture of your own self-exploration. My own background is in video and performance art, but I'm hoping that doesn't influence you and that you'll find your own ways of externalizing the internal. At the end of the Summer, this class has been invited, along with several others in the area, to participate in a show of High-School art at the Neighborhood Activity Center. The title of the show will be "Brotherhood and Community: Art as Dialogue." I think the "Brotherhood" theme ties in nicely with the theme of self-discovery that I'd like to emphasize in this class. Are there any questions so far? (she's completely lost them) Great...
dialogue.name: dialogue

She returns to the bathroom. Several minutes pass. TRACK TWO begins on the LP. She (and we) slowly begin to take notice. It's a strange, haunting old BLUES RECORD. direction.raw_text: It's the next day. Enid has set up a GARAGE SALE in front of her apartment building. Rebecca arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trendy young HIPSTER happens along and looks through the clothes, then to the table where he picks up a ridiculous looking stuffed animal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The HIPSTER looks around a little more and then leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple is browsing. The GIRL, a severely skinny, CLUBHOPPER TYPE in platform shoes looks at the clothes; the BOY, a long haired SKATEBOARDER, goes through her records.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enid turns to the boy - he's holding some records and a book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stomp off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is it? I can't believe you're selling some of this stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck it. Everything must go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my god, I remember this hat... this was during your little old lady phase...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not for sale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (noticing price tag) Wait, it says five dollars...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's a mistake -- I decided not to sell it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was that all about? I thought everything must go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah right, like I'm gonna let some asshole with a goatee own Goofy Gus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much is this dress?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my god, you're selling that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (long pause) That's five hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're crazy -- it should be like two dollars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was wearing that dress the day I lost my virginity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well why do I care about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you even want it? It would look stupid on you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, fuck you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put that stuff back, it's not for sale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this? Some fuckin' joke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! Go away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now are you going to get a regular job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defeated, quiet) Don't worry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it makes you feel any better, I don't think you could've gotten more than ten bucks for all this stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Twenty minutes later. Most of the stuff is gone. Enid packs up one last box to carry inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She heads toward the stairs with the box. Rebecca watches her go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to do something tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't, it's Seymour's birthday... (suddenly) Shit! What time is it?  I have to go to the store! I was going to make him a cake...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (miffed, sighs) Well, are we still going shopping tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I guess... call me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since when can you make a cake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid presents Seymour with a HOSTESS CUPCAKE with a single lit candle in the center. The lights are off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans forward and blows out the candle, then abruptly straightens up and holds the small of his back in pain. Enid turns the lights back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She notices him adjust something under his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets up and looks through his shelves for a record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone RINGS. Seymour ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After several more RINGS the machine picks up and we hear Seymour's message. After the BEEP there's a long fumbling pause...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can open your eyes now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... uh, thanks a lot Enid... I really appreciate it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Doofus... blow it out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Arrrghhh! Ah Jeez... Christ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just my stupid back. I'll be all right in a minute...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... uh... It's just this elastic thing I have to wear for lumbar support...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, like a girdle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe now you understand why I can't get a date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, you're not the only one. Everybody I know has totally fucked up problems... It seems like only stupid people have good relationships...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically cheering her on) That's the spirit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I'm eighteen years old and I've never even had a real, steady boyfriend for more than like two weeks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm starting to think that even if I did get a girlfriend it really wouldn't change anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. It's not like it makes all your problems go away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then again, that's easy for me to say, since I'll never even get a date. I'm sure you have hundreds of guys who are interested in you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, I've got a total crush on this one guy right now, but it's a really fucked-up situation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh wait, you met him... remember that guy Josh? I'm like practically obsessed with him, but I can't do anything about it because Becky would freak out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind, it's way too complicated... (pause) Did you have problems like this when you were my age - where you're totally confused all the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't even dignify that with a response.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at his records) I wonder if you really like all these old records or if you only like the fact that nobody else likes them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a sore subject) Who knows?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you going to get that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let the machine get it. I have no desire to talk to anyone who would be calling me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew it... it's my mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... HI!  Uh... I'm calling for... um... you placed an ad in the Weekly over a month ago and... well, I'm the redhead in the yellow dress... at least I think I am... I saw the ad when you first placed it but I was in this relationship at the time so I cut it out, and now I'm not in the relationship anymore... (giggles) God, this is really confusing... anyway, if you still want to talk to me I can be reached at KL5-2603, that's my work number and my name is Dana... um... BYE!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow! (feigning ignorance) What was that all about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just somebody's idea of a joke...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That didn't sound like a joke to me... what, did you write a personal ad or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still confused) Uh yeah. A long time ago... she called before once... it's just somebody trying to humiliate me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seymour! I promise you that wasn't a joke -- you have to call her back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you be so sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, uh... I'm an expert-about stuff like this -- she was totally for real!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid enters - a light is on in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks slowly to the kitchen - a suspenseful moment. She sees, first, her Dad (wearing an apron) and then, a hauntingly familiar MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Pumpkin? Could you come in here for a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pumpkin, do you remember Maxine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Enid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. (to Dad) Look, I'm kind of tired - I think I'll go to bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I made spaghetti. Do you want some?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: really have to get up early for class tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's really quite something to see you all grown up like this, Enid. (no response from Enid) I'd love to hear about what you're doing. I can't help but feel that I had some small part in how you turned out... (another silent pause) What are you studying? You were always such a smart little girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm taking a remedial high school art class for fuck-ups and retards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A toothy, zit-covered 14-YEAR-OLD BOY poses with a very poorly- made sculpture. A flash goes off and he jumps slightly, sending pieces of his sculpture flying. It's Roberta, taking photos. She moves on to Enid, in front of her big painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enid ad-libs a weird expression as... the flash goes off. Roberta now turns to address the class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long "poignant" pause as she smiles admiringly at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The students get their things together and file out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives her a booklet and an application form.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Smile, Enid...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to miss you people... I feel that we've all done a lot of growing this summer. I hope that each of you feels as though you'll be taking away something from this experience; I know I certainly will be...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember, the art show is this Saturday at seven-thirty sharp. Try to get there at least 15 minutes early.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enid, can I talk to you for a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry - it's nothing bad. I was just wondering what your plans were for next year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not really sure - working, I guess...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I know this is really short notice, but I got a call from a very close friend at the Academy of Art & Design and she tells me that I'm allowed to place one student from your graduating class in a one year scholarship program... and, well, I hope you don't mind, Enid, but I took the liberty of submitting your name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As far as I know it includes housing and meals and everything... it is really quite an offer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) So what do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno... Would I have to take classes and stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me know as soon as you can, Enid. This could be a great thing for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid & Rebecca are in a Crate & Barrel-type store looking at housewares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca spots some particularly fetching dishware.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think one of us should fuck Josh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, you're really obsessed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am not -- I just think it'd be funny to see what he'd do...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we decided that Josh was way too cool to be interested in sex, and that he's the only decent person left in the world and we would never want to bring him down to our level and all that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but maybe one of us should at least try...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No matter what happened it would be a big disaster... Let's just try and keep everything the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, we have to get these...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't afford stuff like this right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sick of waiting - we need to start getting stuff if we're ever going to move. (pause, sees towels) Aren't these the greatest towels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you care about this kind of stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you want nice stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't imagine spending money on towels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to. I'll pay for all the stuff right now and you can pay me back when you finally get a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're insane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still want to go to that thing tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That guy's band is playing tonight... Alien Autopsy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah... maybe... Seymour's going on his big date tonight and I kind of want to be around when he calls, so I can hear how bad it went.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, I'm so sick of Seymour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Seymour is just finishing the dinner DANA has cooked for them at her place. Dana is an attractive redhead, about 40.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dana heads for the kitchen. Seymour gets up to relieve his backache. He walks over to a framed photo on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drags him around. He's still holding his ice cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his ice cream and puts it on a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shuts off the stereo as he sits and eats his ice cream.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That was great - jeez, thanks again for cooking all this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh I love to cook. I guess most women wouldn't invite a man over on the first date, but I believe you should trust your instincts. When I talked to you on the phone you just seemed so... I don't know... harmless. Ready for ice cream?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here we are... it's mocha mint from Lickety Splits. Oh, isn't that photograph just heart-rending?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah ... where is this? Bosnia?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was it Bosnia? I forget... (pause) It's so sad, the tragedy of an entire country eloquently captured in the face of one little boy. (pause) A Soul/Funk song starts up on the radio that catches her attention. She goes over and turns it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I just love this song! Isn't it great? Doesn't it make you want to dance? C'mon!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, well, that's okay - I don't dance, heh, heh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be silly, anyone can dance. Here, just follow me... watch my feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon Seymour, it's all in your mind. Just loosen up and feel the music! Here, put down your bowl of ice cream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (checking his watch) Hey, it's nearly nine already - we're gonna have to leave now if we're going to make that movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, all right... Party-pooper! Just let me put a few things away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so excited to see this film - Dustoffvarnya is such a brilliant director! Did you see his last film, The Flower That Drank The Moon? It was simply glorious!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, no. I missed that one. But what do I know? I like Laurel and Hardy movies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? I never really cared for those. Why does the fat one always have to be so mean to the skinny one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's 9:30 PM. Enid is drawing in her sketchbook. She looks impatiently at the phone. Time passes - it's 11 PM. She can't stand it anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour picks up the phone. Dana is in the background getting some ice in the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. Enid is stunned... Now what? She calls Rebecca.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, it's me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hi...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost whispering) Actually, it's kind of still happening... she's over here right now... I think everything's going pretty well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? You're kidding me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, so I better go -- it's not really the best time to talk...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, are you going to like have sex with her on your first date?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Enid... I'll talk to you later... bye!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rebecca is sitting on the couch in her pajamas when the phone RINGS. She picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca hangs up. Clearly, she's not going anywhere.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still want to do something tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to Seymour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still shocked by this) I can't believe it - he actually scored!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How repulsive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So should I come over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, I'm just about to go out with some friends...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about? Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just some people from work...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah well, you said you were busy... look, I'd better get going... I'll call you tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid stands outside Josh's door. A tentative pause; then she knocks. Josh opens the door, stunned. Enid is wearing an uncharacteristically "sexy" outfit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi... what's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I come in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She goes in and looks around nervously... the note (Tiffany & Amber) is tacked to the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Enid sits down on futon/sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up half-finished beer and drinks self-consciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josh doesn't respond - there's another awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits, tentatively. Long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stunned pause, then she bravely leans forward and kisses him.  He kisses back but she is clearly the aggressor... they get more and more into it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you the one who left that note?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... I'm totally confused...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit over here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want something to drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean "why"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you trying to get me wasted so you can take advantage of my womanly charms?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Yeah, right"... well why not?  What's so wrong with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why do you hate me so much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did I say I hated you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've never once said anything even remotely nice to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make me nervous! I always feel like you're going out of your way to make me feel uncomfortable so you can laugh at me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just the way I am!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well -- ENID It's just my stupid way of getting attention! God, I practically love you, Josh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have any protection?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . - 1 AM. Later, post-coital on the now unfolded futon... Enid lies on her back, Josh is face-down on top of her with his head to the side. Enid has a blank, disillusioned stare.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (now he's romantic and sappy) You must have known all along how I -- you know -- how I felt about you -- it must be totally obvious...  God... I always used to dream about this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring ahead) Why do you have that stupid poster?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's the next morning. Josh is asleep. Enid, fully awake and dressed, sits on the bed looking at him, thoroughly disillusioned. She pulls out a record from his collection and grimaces. She opens a closet door and finds an electric guitar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (waking up, groggy, happily surprised) Oh, hi...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do all guys have to play stupid guitars? It's so typical... Either they're into cars or guns or sports or guitars... it's so obvious...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long have you been up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't sleep... I should get going; I feel really weird...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to go get breakfast somewhere?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think we should... Look, you have to totally promise me you won't tell Becky about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because if you do, I'll kill you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay... I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just take my word for it... if she ever finds out about this I'll never hear the end of it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rebecca is dressed in her best apartment-hunting outfit. She sits on her bed, dialing the phone with the FREE WEEKLY open on her lap. She circles something with her pen while the phone rings.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goddammit, bitch -- where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid lies perfectly still on her bed, staring at the ceiling while the phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Establish the restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour sits alone eating lunch. We see Enid approach stealthily from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits across from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour looks again at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, Dana enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dana sits next to Seymour, facing Enid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour begins to stammer some kind of response.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very startled)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where have you been? I've been looking all over for you... I've been wandering the streets day and night trying to find you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, actually Joe told me you were here... so how come you never call me anymore?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I'm sorry... I-I've been really busy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I'll bet! So, how's it going with what's-her-name? Dana?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (he looks nervously at his watch) Oh... pretty well, surprisingly... you know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what kind of stuff do you guys do together? Is she into old records and stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sort of... she doesn't dislike any of that stuff... she's trying, anyway... actually, we're supposed to go antique shopping for her apartment this afternoon...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not convinced) Sounds good...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We really should get together sometime soon... I-I'll definitely call you this week -- ENID What, are you trying to get rid of me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to this stupid art show and I want you to be my date... There's something I have to show you...

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) So that's it? You don't ever want to see me again?

dialogue.raw_text: (not sure what to say; long pause) I don't know... I'm sorry, but Dana's a very jealous person. I just don't want to screw that up right now... I'm sure she'll dump me soon and we can go back to being friends...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What do you mean?

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it's a good idea... it's our plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how are you gonna pay rent and everything? You don't even have a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get a job tomorrow, I promise. If I don't, you can totally tell me to fuck off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid is putting on her shoes. Her Dad opens the door slightly and sticks his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, three sharp KNOCKS on the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad goes to answer the door. Enid hides in her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enid looks out the window and sees Seymour walking away. She has a terribly sad look on her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pumpkin, are you in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you going to yell at me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I heard about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was in a horrible mood - tell her not to worry, I'll be completely out of her life in a few days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She understands what you're going through and she really wants to help you. She says that job at Computer Station is still available if you want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I-I'm not sure... yeah, maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, I was just checking to see if you were here - your friend Seymour is on his way up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean "on his way up"!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just buzzed him in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong with you?! Tell him I'm not here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I can't -- ENID JUST DO IT!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm not sure when she'll be back...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Seymour sits in dim light, dialing an antique "candlestick" telephone. In the background, a Peter, Paul and Mary concert plays on the TV. We hear three rings followed by Enid's answering machine message. He hangs up before it finishes. Joe walks by the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour doesn't answer. He looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again no answer from Seymour, he stares off into space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour looks so miserable that even Joe has some compassion for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe leaves. Seymour is left listening to the record.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, here's where the fun never stops!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I'm really, really happy. Really having a good time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still torturing yourself over that Enid, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where else am I ever going to find another girl who likes Geeshie Wiley records? (pause) She could at least have the decency to call me back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe she was just using you to try and get back at some guy. Who knows? It could be a million things. It's wasted time trying to logically figure out the female brain, that's for sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe she's got another boyfriend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bummed out, wants Joe to stop) Yeah, well... thanks for cheering me up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deadpan) No problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at it this way - at least things can't get any worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Seymour is at work, walking down a carpeted hallway with many doors on both sides. A door opens and a Tony Robbins- ish, 35 year-old MANAGEMENT EXECUTIVE sticks his head out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plunks down the current issue of THE FREE WEEKLY - it's open to a 1/2 page article on page 8 with the headline "Oh Brother!" and a photo of THE PAINTING being removed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Seymour! Just the man I want to see. Step in here for a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What can you tell me about this, Seymour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & REBECCA'S NEW APT. Enid is wearing a bright orange "Computer Station" T-shirt and a yellow vest with a "trainee" tag. She's looking around at her new home: a hopelessly drab, characterless apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enid points to a small box with sketchbook, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drags Enid into the kitchen and opens a BUILT-IN IRONING BOARD as though it's the most amazing thing she's ever-seen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, whaddya think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So where's all your stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all you're bringing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna finish packing tonight... I'll bring it over tomorrow sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make sure you're here by noon - we have tons of stuff to do... Oh yeah! I have to show you something else!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't this the greatest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enid is sorting her stuff into boxes. Digging through her closet, she finds a box that she doesn't recognize. Inside are her old children's records (45's). She excitedly takes one out and plays it. She folds her clothes while listening to this song, which clearly is getting to her. She grabs mechanically for the next thing hanging in her closet. It's the uniform from her job at "Computer Station." She folds it, puts it in the box, then stops, staring at the orange fabric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . - THE NEXT DAY Rebecca is nervously arranging and re-arranging her stuff. She puts up her gigantic new kitchen wall clock and sets the time to 12:45. She goes to the phone and calls Enid. The machine picks up and Rebecca hangs up. She does another tedious, pointless task. IT'S NOW 3:30. She's pissed off and goes to the phone to call again. As it rings there's a knock on the door. Relieved, she hangs up and goes to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Seymour standing there, not Enid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca goes over and gets Enid's sketchbook out of the box and flips through it. When she gets to the right page she hands it to Seymour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a pasted-up PERSONAL AD beside a DRAWING OF SEYMOUR in Wowsville. On the facing page we see a drawing of JOSH with his name surrounded by RED HEARTS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as she opens the door) What's wrong with you, retard - it's three-thirty!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... hi. Uh... Enid's stepmother told me I'd find her here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's not at home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... they said she was here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck is she doing?! She was supposed to be here three hours ago!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, do you mind if I wait? I really need to talk to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (allows him to step inside but leaves the door open) Are you sure she wasn't there?  Maybe she was just hiding from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would she be hiding from me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know... where is she, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe she's with Josh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Josh!? Why would she be with Josh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? What did she tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She just mentioned him a few times and said that they had been dating - I thought maybe she was...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Is she having some secret affair with Josh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no idea - I just want to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why wouldn't she tell me? There's no way! She could never keep that to herself... you're crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really, I don't know enough about it to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That slut!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (changing subject back to me) Why did you say she might be hiding from me? Did she say anything to you about me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting revenge on Seymour) Yeah, she thinks you're a dork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did she say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, what do you expect?  Considering how we met you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On that pathetic fake blind date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't she ever tell you about that? God, she really is pathological...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What fake blind date? What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here. Read it and weep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Seymour's car screeches into the parking lot. He bursts into the store, ready for once in his life to make a scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josh is behind the counter cleaning the Slurpee machine, with his back to the entrance, as Seymour storms in. Doug is over by the magazine rack reading a dirt bike magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josh turns around - what's going on? He recognizes Seymour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he says this he flips over a SMALL DISPLAY RACK of potato chips. Then he tries to flip over a BIG DISPLAY CASE in front of the counter but is unable to budge it - he keeps trying and gets more and more frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Josh runs from behind the counter to stop him before he creates a huge mess. He tries to grab Seymour and they get into a ridiculous frantic scuffle. Seymour starts yelling. Suddenly Doug appears and gets Seymour in a choke hold with his nunchucks. Doug ad-libs cop-style jargon. Josh is freaked out. Seymour realizes what a fool he is and starts to cry. The Boss comes out of the back room...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you had a good laugh at my expense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh... oh... hi... uh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to see something funny? I'll show you something funny!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Josh! What going on here?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & REBECCA'S APARTMENT - AROUND MIDNIGHT The apartment is dark - lit only by a harsh, annoying streetlight. Rebecca sits on the couch in sweat clothes, exasperated. She goes to look out the window. Cars with loud radios can be heard driving by. She goes to the phone - she checks it and hangs up. Pause. She picks it up again - one last try. She dials the number and waits. We hear the BEEP of the answering machine. Rebecca hangs up. She gets into a sleeping bag (spread out in the center of a cold linoleum floor). She zips the zipper all the way over her head and curls up into a whimpering ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "SEVERAL MONTHS LATER" INT. THERAPIST'S OFFICE - DAY The dialogue begins in voice-over as the title card fades. We slowly fade in to see Seymour, lying on a pink pastel psychiatrist's couch, as he speaks to his THERAPIST, a handsome, well-coiffed woman in her late 40s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour looks up. She nods toward the large wall clock behind her: thirty seconds after five. Re gets up and she walks him slowly toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause. They stand facing each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seymour takes a filled-out check from his shirt pocket. In the waiting room, we see SEYMOUR'S MOTHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they leave Seymour looks back and smiles weakly at the doctor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have to admit, things have really started looking up for me since my life turned to shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So tell me more about this job. What exactly will you be doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, mostly archival research, cataloguing old records and writing liner notes for their CD reissues. It's really... I can't believe it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember what I said when we first started -- this little breakdown might turn out to be the best thing that ever happened to you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't pay very much, but I should be able to afford my own place in a few months... Do you think that's too soon? I'm really anxious to get my record collection out of storage...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't we start with that next week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as she opens the door) Don't thank me. You're doing all the work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seymour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have a check for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seymour? Are you done? Did you have a chance to think about what you might want for dinner while you were in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can talk about it in the car, Ma...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Cafe has been FULLY REMODELED and now resembles Wowsville more than the old Quality Cafe. There are no neighborhood "characters" anymore, only well-heeled twenty-somethings. We see that Rebecca is now a waitress here. She tears off a check and places it in front of a super-muscular, polo shirted EUROPEAN HIPSTER, who is too busy tapping away at his POWERBOOK to notice. She walks toward the end of the counter to total up her receipts. She looks up and sees Enid, wearing tasteful 1930's style clothes, sitting across from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see at this point that Rebecca & Enid are no longer friends, but there are also no hard feelings evident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca goes to get it. Enid looks around, bemused and saddened by what The Quality Cafe has become.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a crumpled envelope from her pocket and pulls out her DIPLOMA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Josh enters. Enid turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment it's not clear who he's talking to, and then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finishes, takes off her apron and emerges from behind the counter. She kisses Josh perfunctorily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rebecca & Josh leave. Enid is totally alone in the now-alien world of the Quality Cafe. A momentary pause as she calmly stares into her orange juice. We see a small, round TRAVEL BAG at her feet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hi... I almost didn't recognize you -- I think I need to get glasses; you're all blurry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding toward muscular HIPSTER) You're lucky then, you can't see the veins on that guy's biceps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, he's a really nice guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe an orange juice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, look what I got...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow... finally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It just came yesterday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi Enid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey Josh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you ready to go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still counting receipts) Yeah, just one second...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Josh) Did you remember to pay the phone bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Enid) Call me sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Definitely. We still have to go to that shoe store sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Enid walking down the familiar streets of her world. It's early evening, quiet except for distant street noises. She walks toward the old ACME SHOES AND REPAIR STORE. It looks the same, miraculously preserved, until she stands right in front of it. She looks through the partially papered over window and sees WORKMEN inside installing new fixtures: a modern counter and several small tables, all made from a FAMILIAR GREEN PLASTIC. A sign in the window reads: "Coming Soon: Another COFFEE EXPERIENCE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues walking as the sun has set and there is a calm stillness to the city. She turns a corner and is startled by her reflection in a large window made of one-way glass. She stops and looks at herself. Everything about her looks perfect for once; no need to change a thing. She moves closer to the glass and, shading her eyes, tries to look inside. She continues walking. Darkness is just setting in and she has the street all to herself.
direction.name: direction
